importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the report's publication indicates the most up-to-date evidence of North Korea’s involvement in the war in Ukraine, signaling ongoing developments in the conflict.
The date of the drone attack on Kherson in September 2024 marks the event when the North Korean submunition was first used, establishing a timeline for the weapon’s deployment.
The date when North Korea began sending troops to Russia marks the start of direct military involvement, signaling a significant escalation in support for Russia.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from 2024 to 2025 reflects the escalation of North Korea’s military support to Russia, including the production and deployment of weapons and troops.

keyTakeAways: A North Korean submunition was found in a drone used to attack Ukraine in September 2024, marking a direct material link between North Korea and the war in Ukraine.
The submunition was marked with Korean characters referencing the Juche calendar, indicating it was produced in the year Juche 89, equivalent to 2000 in the Gregorian calendar.
The submunition was originally designed for rocket artillery but was modified for use on a first-person-view drone using basic materials like wooden sticks, wire, and duct tape.
This discovery shows North Korea’s active role in supplying weapons to Russia, supporting its drone attacks on Ukrainian cities and civilian infrastructure.

Russia has rapidly expanded its drone production, with a massive drone factory enabling it to launch thousands of cheap, low-tech drones in a single night to overwhelm Ukrainian defenses and undermine civilian morale.
North Korea has ramped up its weapons program and sent approximately 12,000 troops to Russia, with around 4,000 reported killed or wounded as of 2025.
The findings by Conflict Armament Research (CAR) provide critical evidence of North Korea’s material and logistical support to Russia’s war effort in Ukraine.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A North Korean submunition, marked with Juche calendar references indicating a 2000 production date, was found in a drone used to attack the Ukrainian port city of Kherson in September 2024. The submunition, originally designed for rocket artillery, was repurposed for a first-person-view drone using basic materials. The discovery, reported by Conflict Armament Research (CAR), establishes a direct material link between North Korea and Russia’s war in Ukraine. This occurs amid Russia’s large-scale drone attacks and production, and North Korea’s increased military involvement, including the deployment of approximately 12,000 troops to Russia, with around 4,000 reported casualties. The findings signal a growing level of international military cooperation in the war, raising concerns about the global spread of asymmetric warfare tactics.
title: North Korean submunition found in drone used to attack Ukraine, report finds
